conclusion: The problem involves determining which blocks a toy car will collide with and where it will stop based on power, collision, and deflection effects.
The image shows several blocks of different colors arranged on a green surface, with a toy car approaching from the right side.

There are multiple groups of blocks: a blue stack (two blocks), an orange and red stack (three blocks: orange on top, red in the middle, red at the bottom), a green stack (two blocks), and a single yellow block.
The toy car is gray with red and black details and is approaching from the right side towards the orange and red stack.
The task is to predict the path of the car and determine which blocks it will hit, considering positions and possible collisions.
The green surface is flat, and the blocks are placed on it. The car is moving from the right side towards the left, passing through the blocks.
The car approaches the orange and red stack and hits the orange block first since it is on top.
When the car hits the orange block, it might push it, causing the orange block to move and possibly collide with other blocks.
The orange block is close to the blue stack, so if the car pushes the orange block, the orange block might bump into the blue blocks.
The car might continue its path and hit other blocks as well.
The sequence of events to consider includes: car hits orange block, orange block hits blue blocks, car hits red blocks, and possibly car hits green blocks or the single yellow block.
The car is coming from the right side and moving towards the left, with the orange and red stack positioned more towards the center-left from the car's starting point.
When the car hits the orange block, it will apply a force that makes the orange block move to the left.
